Djokovic went on to reach the [[2013 US Open – Men's singles|US Open final]], where he met Nadal for the 37th time in his career (a new Open Era record). He went on to lose in four sets.{{cite web |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/10/sports/tennis/nadal-beats-djokovic-to-win-us-open.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130910013258/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/10/sports/tennis/nadal-beats-djokovic-to-win-us-open.html |archive-date=10 September 2013 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |author=Christopher Clarey |title=Nadal Beats Djokovic to Win U.S. Open |date=9 September 2013 |access-date=15 November 2020}} In early October, Djokovic collected his fourth Beijing title by defeating Nadal in the final in straight sets. He also collected his second Shanghai Masters title, extending his winning streak to 20–0 over the last two seasons at the hard-court Asian swing of the tour.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/tennis/2013/10/13/novak-djokovic-juan-martin-del-potro-shanghai-masters/2975329/ |title=Djokovic beats del Potro to win Shanghai Masters |date=13 October 2013 |work=USA Today |access-date=3 November 2013}} Djokovic won his 16th Masters title in Paris at the end of the season, beating David Ferrer in the final.{{cite news |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2013-11-03/novak-djokovic-defeats-david-ferrer-to-win-paris-masters-title |title=Djokovic Beats Ferrer to Win Paris Masters Title |date=3 November 2013 |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |access-date=5 November 2013}} At the [[2013 ATP World Tour Finals|2013 ATP Finals]] Djokovic retained his trophy, beating Nadal in straight sets.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2013/nov/11/novak-djokovic-rafael-nadal-world-tour-finals |title=Djokovic denies Nadal last word in the World Tour Finals |date=12 November 2013 |work=The Guardian |access-date=18 November 2013}} At the end of the season, [[Boris Becker]] joined his staff as head coach. ====2014: Second Wimbledon title, four Masters titles, and return to No. 1==== {{Main|2014 Novak Djokovic tennis season}} Djokovic began the year with a warmup tournament win, the [[2013 Mubadala World Tennis Championship – Singles|2013 Mubadala Championship]]. At the [[2014 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]], he won his first four matches in straight sets against [[Lukáš Lacko]], [[Leonardo Mayer]], [[Denis Istomin]], and No. 15 seed [[Fabio Fognini]] respectively. He met Wawrinka in the quarterfinals of the tournament, the second consecutive year the two had met at the event. Despite coming back from two sets to one down, Djokovic fell 9–7 in the fifth set, ending his 25–match winning streak in Melbourne, as well as his streak of 14 consecutive Grand Slam tournament semi-finals.{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/tennis/aus14/story/_/id/10326661/australian-open-tomas-berdych-stanislas-wawrinka-reach-aussie-semifinals |title=Stanislas Wawrinka Ousts Djokovic |date=21 January 2014 |publisher=ESPN |access-date=21 January 2014}} Djokovic won his third [[Indian Wells Masters]] title, defeating Federer in the final. Continuing his good run, he beat No. 1 Nadal in the final of the [[2014 Sony Open Tennis – Men's singles|Miami Masters]] in straight sets.{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/tennis/story/_/id/10698891/novak-djokovic-rolls-rafael-nadal-win-fourth-sony-open-title |title=Novak Djokovic rolls Rafael Nadal win fourth Sony Open title |date=30 March 2014 |publisher=ESPN |access-date=15 July 2014}} Suffering from a wrist injury which hampered him throughout the [[2014 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters|Monte-Carlo Masters]], Djokovic lost the semi-finals to Federer in straight sets. After returning from injury, Djokovic won his third Rome title by beating Nadal in the final of the [[2014 Italian Open (tennis)|Italian Open]].{{cite news |publisher=BBC |title=Novak Djokovic beats Rafael Nadal to win Italian Open in Rome |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/tennis/27462782 |date=18 May 2014 |access-date=18 May 2014}} He subsequently donated the $500,000 in prize money that he had received to the victims of the [[2014 Southeast Europe floods]].{{cite news |publisher=B92 |title=Đoković donirao 500.000 dolara! |url=http://www.b92.net/sport/tenis/vesti.php?yyyy=2014&mm=05&dd=19&nav_id=850243 |date=19 May 2014 |access-date=19 May 2014}} Djokovic reached the final of the [[2014 French Open|French Open]] losing only two sets in six matches but lost in the final to Nadal in four sets. It was Djokovic's first defeat in the last 5 matches between both. At the [[2014 Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon Championships]] Djokovic defeated [[Roger Federer]] in the [[2014 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final|final]] in five sets. With this victory he replaced Rafael Nadal again as the world No. 1.{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2014/06/27/Wimbledon-Final-Djokovic-Federer.aspx |title=Djokovic returns to No. 1 with Wimbledon victory |date=6 July 2014 |publisher=ATP |access-date=7 July 2014}} Djokovic played at the [[2014 Rogers Cup|Rogers Cup]], losing to eventual first-time champion [[Jo-Wilfried Tsonga]] in straight sets.{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/tennis/news/12040/9410311/atp-rogers-cup-top-seed-novak-djokovic-beaten-by-jo-wilfried-tsonga-in-toronto |title=ATP Toronto Masters: Top seed Novak Djokovic beaten by Jo-Wilfried Tsonga |date=8 August 2014 |publisher=ATP |access-date=12 August 2014}} He followed that with a loss to Tommy Robredo at the Cincinnati Masters. At the [[2014 US Open (tennis)|US Open]], Djokovic reached the semi-finals, where he lost in four sets to [[Kei Nishikori]].{{cite web |title=Nishikori register historic victory over Djokovic |date=6 September 2014 |url=http://www.india.com/sports/novak-djokovic-vs-kei-nishikori-live-updates-us-open-2014-semi-final-141877/ |access-date=6 September 2014}} Djokovic returned to Beijing with a fifth trophy in six years, defeating Murray in the semi-final and Berdych in the final.{{cite news |title=Novak Djokovic beats Tomas Berdych to win fifth China Open |publisher=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/tennis/29497855 |access-date=6 October 2014}} The following week he was beaten by Federer in the semi-final of [[2014 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles|Shanghai Masters]]. He then won the [[2014 BNP Paribas Masters – Singles|Paris Bercy masters title]], without losing a single set, beating Raonic in the final.{{cite news |title=Novak Djokovic beats Milos Raonic to retain Paris Masters title |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/nov/02/novak-djokovic-paris-masters-milos-raonic |work=The Guardian |access-date=7 July 2016}} In the ATP Finals, Djokovic created a record by winning three round-robin matches with a loss of just nine games. By reaching the semi-final, he also secured the year-end No. 1 ranking for the third time, tying him with Nadal in the fifth position. He was awarded the [[2014 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles|ATP Finals]] trophy after Federer withdrew before the final.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/tennis/30074849 |title=Roger Federer out of ATP World Tour final v Novak Djokovic |date=16 November 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=16 November 2014}} This marked the seventh title of the season for him and the fourth title at the year-end event. ==== 2015: One of the greatest tennis seasons of all time ==== {{Main|2015 Novak Djokovic tennis season}} Djokovic began the season at the [[2015 Qatar ExxonMobil Open|Qatar Open]] in Doha, where he won his first two rounds for the loss of just 6 games, however, lost in the quarterfinals against [[Ivo Karlović]] in three tight sets. He rebounded from this defeat well at the [[2015 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]], where he made it through the first five rounds without dropping a set. In the semi-finals, he faced defending champion [[Stan Wawrinka]], the man who beat him the previous year. He twice lost a set lead, however, came roaring back in the fifth to take it to love, and set up a third final against [[Andy Murray]]. After splitting the first two sets in tiebreakers, Djokovic found his form after dropping his serve at the start of the third set, going on to win 12 of the last 13 games to record a four-set victory over the Scot, and win an Open Era record-breaking fifth title in Melbourne, overtaking [[Roger Federer]] and [[Andre Agassi]].{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/tennis/australianopen/11382628/Andy-Murray-beaten-by-Novak-Djokovic-in-Australian-Open-final.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220110/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/tennis/australianopen/11382628/Andy-Murray-beaten-by-Novak-Djokovic-in-Australian-Open-final.html |archive-date=10 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |title=Andy Murray beaten by Novak Djokovic in Australian Open final |date=1 February 2015 |work=The Daily Telegraph |access-date=2 February 2015 |location=London, UK |first=Simon |last=Briggs}}{{cbignore}} He moved into equal eighth on the all-time list of men with the most Major titles, tying Agassi, [[Ivan Lendl]], [[Jimmy Connors]], [[Ken Rosewall]] and [[Fred Perry]].{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2015/01/4/Australian-Open-Sunday-Final-Djokovic-Murray.aspx |title=DJOKOVC MAKES HISTORY AT AUSTRALIAN OPEN |access-date=1 February 2015}} [[File:Novak Djokovic, Qatar Open 2016.jpg|thumb|300px|Djokovic sliding on a hard court to get a ball back.]] He next competed at the [[2015 Dubai Tennis Championships|Dubai Championships]] and lost to Federer in the final.{{cite web |url=http://www.dnevnik.rs/sport/djokovic-izgubio-od-federera-u-finalu-dubaija |script-title=sr:Ђоковић изгубио од Федерера у финалу Дубаија |date=28 February 2015 |work=[[Dnevnik (Serbia)|Dnevnik]] |language=sr |access-date=28 February 2015}} After 2 weeks, Djokovic defeated [[John Isner]] and Andy Murray en route to his 21st [[ATP Tour Masters 1000|Masters]] title, beating Federer in three sets in [[2015 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|Indian Wells]].{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/03/22/tennis/tennis-indian-wells-federer-djokovic |title=Novak Djokovic battles past Roger Federer for Indian Wells title |date=23 March 2015 |publisher=CNN |access-date=27 March 2015}} In [[2015 Miami Open – Men's singles|Miami]], he defeated David Ferrer and John Isner en route to winning his fifth title defeating Andy Murray in three sets. With his 22nd Masters title, Djokovic became the first player to complete the [[Miami Open (tennis)#Sunshine Double|Indian Wells – Miami title double]] three times.{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2015/03/13/Miami-Sunday-Final-Djokovic-Murray.aspx |title=Djokovic Makes History With Fifth Miami Title |date=5 April 2015 |work=ATP World Tour |access-date=6 April 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2015/03/13/Miami-Final-Set-by-Set.aspx |title=Dominant Djokovic: How The Miami Final Was Won |date=5 April 2015 |work=ATP World Tour |access-date=6 April 2015}} In April, Djokovic clinched his second [[2018 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles|Monte-Carlo Masters]] by beating Tomáš Berdych in the final.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/tennis/32373219 |title=Novak Djokovic beats Tomas Berdych to win Monte Carlo title |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=19 April 2015}} Djokovic withdrew from the 2015 Madrid Masters.{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/tennis/story/_/id/12792096/novak-djokovic-withdraws-mutua-madrid-open |title=Novak Djokovic withdraws from Mutua Madrid Open |date=30 April 2015 |access-date=10 May 2015}} He won the title for the fourth time at the [[2015 Italian Open – Men's singles|Rome Masters]], making it 4 out of 4 titles in Masters events entered by Djokovic in the season. He continued his good form on clay at the [[2015 French Open – Men's singles|French Open]] by reaching the final without dropping a set in the first five rounds, including a quarterfinal clash with [[Rafael Nadal|Nadal]] and a five-set semi-final victory over No. 3 seed Andy Murray which took two days to complete. This meant he became only the second man to have won against Nadal at the French Open. However, he lost the next match and the tournament to No. 8 seed [[Stan Wawrinka]] in four sets.{{cite web |title=Stanislas Wawrinka stuns Novak Djokovic to win French Open |first=Piers |last=Newbery |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 June 2015 |access-date=8 June 2015 |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/tennis/33042056}} Five weeks later, he rebounded again from the tough loss in Paris, just like 2014, coming from two sets down to beat [[Kevin Anderson (tennis)|Kevin Anderson]] in the fourth round, and then going on to claim his third [[2015 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|Wimbledon]] title, with a four-set win over Roger Federer.{{cite web |title=Djokovic sweeps to third Wimbledon title |first=Ron |last=Atkin |publisher=[[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] |date=12 July 2015 |access-date=12 July 2015 |url=http://www.wimbledon.com/en_GB/news/articles/2015-07-12/djokovic_sweeps_to_third_wimbledon_title.html}} Prior to the final Grand Slam event of the year, Djokovic had the chance to become the first man in history to complete the full set of Masters titles in [[2015 Western & Southern Open|Cincinnati]], achieving the [[ATP Tour Masters 1000#Career Golden Masters|Career Golden Masters]], but he lost the final to Federer (Djokovic would accomplish the feat at the [[2018 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles|2018]] and [[2020 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles|2020]] events).{{cite web |title=Federer defeats Djokovic in straight sets to win Cincinnati Masters |first=Joe |last=Wolfond |publisher=thescore.com |date=23 August 2015 |access-date=25 November 2015 |url=https://www.thescore.com/news/815258}} At the [[2015 US Open – Men's singles|US Open]], Djokovic reached the final for the sixth time in his career, achieving the feat of reaching all four Grand Slam finals in a single calendar year. In the final, he faced Federer once again, defeating him in four sets to win his third Grand Slam title of the year, his second title at Flushing Meadows, and his tenth Grand Slam singles title overall, becoming the fifth man in the Open Era to win double-digit Grand Slam singles titles, as well as only the third man to reach all four Major finals in a calendar year.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/tennis/34241632 |title=US Open 2015: Novak Djokovic beats Roger Federer in final |publisher=BBC Sport |author1=Piers Newbery |date=14 September 2015 |access-date=14 September 2015}} He returned to [[2015 China Open – Men's singles|China Open]] in October, winning the title for the sixth time, defeating Nadal in straight sets in the final to bring his overall record at the tournament to 29–0.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/12/sports/tennis/djokovic-defeats-nadal.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151015061502/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/12/sports/tennis/djokovic-defeats-nadal.html |archive-date=15 October 2015 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |title=Djokovic Defeats Nadal |work=The New York Times |date=12 October 2015 |access-date=13 October 2015}} Djokovic then reached the final of the [[2015 BNP Paribas Masters|Paris Masters]], where he defeated Murray in straight sets, taking his fourth title there and a record sixth ATP Masters tournament in one year.{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-battles-murray-for-paris-2015-title |title=Djokovic battles Murray for Paris 2015 title |publisher=atpworldtour.com |date=12 November 2015 |access-date=22 November 2015}} After losing to Federer in the round-robin stage of the [[2015 ATP World Tour Finals|ATP Finals]] he took on the third seed again in the final. He beat Federer in straight sets winning his fifth ATP Finals title and becoming the first player to win the Year-end Championships four consecutive times.{{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/atp-world-tour-finals-novak-djokovic-dominates-roger-federer-claim-record-fourth-straight-title-1529972 |title=ATP World Tour Finals: Novak Djokovic dominates Roger Federer to claim record fourth straight title |work=International Business Times |date=12 November 2015 |access-date=22 November 2015}} By the end of the season, Djokovic made a season-record 15 consecutive finals, reaching the championship match of every top-level tournament he played (four in Majors, eight in Masters, and the final at the Year-end Championships). He won 11 titles including a season-record 10 [[List of ATP Tour top-level tournament singles champions#Statistics|Big Titles]] (three Majors, six Masters, and the Year-end Championships) on all court surfaces and conditions (hard, clay, grass and indoors). Djokovic set a season record for most ranking points (16,585) accumulated as world No. 1. and had a season-record 31 victories over top-10 players, including a remarkable 15–4 winning record against the other members of the Big Four, Federer, Nadal, and Murray. The 2015 season is Djokovic's most successful season as of 2022, and it is considered one of the greatest seasons in tennis history.{{Cite web |url=https://novakdjokovic.com/en/news/media/novak-sets-gold-standard-in-record-breaking-2015-season/ |title=Novak sets gold standard in record-breaking 2015 season |website=Novak Djokovic}} ====2016: Historic 'Nole Slam', four Masters titles, and ranking points record==== {{Main|2016 Novak Djokovic tennis season}} [[File:Djokovic 2016.jpg|thumb|250px|Djokovic kissing [[Coupe des Mousquetaires]] after winning the [[2016 French Open]], completing "Nole Slam" and the career Grand Slam.]] Djokovic collected his 60th career title in [[2016 Qatar ExxonMobil Open|Doha]], defeating [[Rafael Nadal]] in two sets in a final that lasted 73 minutes. He broke his own ATP ranking points record, bringing it up to 16,790. Djokovic then proceeded to win his sixth [[2016 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]]. On his road to his [[Open Era]] record sixth title in Melbourne, he defeated [[Roger Federer]] in four sets in the semi-finals, and in a rematch of the 2015 final, he defeated [[Andy Murray]], in three straight sets.{{cite news |last1=Ubha |first1=Ravi |title=Australian Open 2016: Novak Djokovic eases past Andy Murray for historic title |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/01/31/tennis/australian-open-tennis-djokovic-murray/index.html |access-date=31 January 2016 |publisher=CNN |date=31 January 2016}} He quickly rebounded from an eye infection at the [[2016 Dubai Tennis Championships – Men's singles|Dubai Open]] to collect a fifth [[2016 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|Indian Wells Masters]] title, defeating Rafael Nadal in the semi-finals, and [[Milos Raonic]] in the final. Djokovic's run was so dominant that the world no. 2 and 3 (Andy Murray and Roger Federer) could have combined their points and still not have had enough to pass him in the rankings.{{cite news |date=31 January 2016 |title=Novak Djokovic grand slam ranking points Roger Federer Andy Murray |work=Fox Sports |url=http://www.foxsports.com/tennis/story/novak-djokovic-grand-slam-ranking-points-roger-federer-andy-murray-no-1-033116 |access-date=31 January 2016}} On 3 April 2016, Djokovic won the [[2016 Miami Open – Men's singles|Miami Open]] for the third consecutive year, and did so without dropping a set en route to his sixth career [[Miami Open (tennis)|Miami Open]] title, tying him with [[Andre Agassi]] for most ever Miami Open men's singles titles.{{cite news |title=Serb notches sixth Miami title |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-wins-sixth-miami-title-2016 |access-date=11 June 2016 |publisher=atpworldtour.com |date=3 April 2016}} In addition, the victory marked the fourth year Djokovic completed the [[Miami Open (tennis)#Sunshine Double|Sunshine Double]] in his career, the most Sunshine Doubles out of any player in history, and 2016 being the third consecutive year that Djokovic completed it. His win in Miami also saw Djokovic surpass Roger Federer to become the all-time leading prize money winner on the ATP tour with career earnings of $98.2 million.{{cite news |title=Djokovic wins 6th Key Biscayne title by beating Nishikori |url=http://m.tennis.com/pro-game/2016/04/djokovic-wins-6th-key-biscayne-title-by-beating-nishikori/58028/ |access-date=3 April 2016 |publisher=m.tennis.com |date=3 April 2016}} After an early round exit at the [[2016 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles|Monte Carlo Masters]],{{cite news |title=World No. 1 reflects on his three-set loss to Vesely |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-reaction-monte-carlo-2016-wednesday |access-date=11 June 2016 |publisher=atpworldtour.com |date=13 April 2016}} Djokovic quickly bounced back by winning the [[2016 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles|Madrid]] title for the second time in his career, with a three-set victory over Murray.{{cite news |title=Serb wins 29th Masters 1000 title |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-murray-madrid-2016-final |access-date=11 June 2016 |publisher=atpworldtour.com |date=8 May 2016}} They met again in the [[2016 Italian Open – Men's singles|Rome Masters]] final one week later with Murray as the victor; despite a sluggish performance, Djokovic defeated Nadal and [[Kei Nishikori]] in two long quarterfinals and semi-finals.{{cite news |title=Serb reflects on challenging week in Rome |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-reaction-rome-2016-final |access-date=11 June 2016 |publisher=atpworldtour.com |date=15 May 2016}} Djokovic defeated Andy Murray in the final of the [[2016 French Open – Men's singles|French Open]] in four sets, making him the reigning champion of all four major tournaments, a historic feat the media dubbed the [[Grand Slam (tennis)#Non-calendar-year Grand Slam|Nole Slam]].{{cite web |date=5 June 2016 |title=FRENCH OPEN: Djokovic eyes Nole Slam; Serena bids for No. 22 |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/3d1b405ad9bf4cbf9fab8fc9950b2b23/french-open-djokovic-eyes-nole-slam-serena-bids-no-22 |access-date=13 June 2016 |agency=[[Associated Press]]}}{{cite web |date=5 June 2016 |title=Avec le 'Nole Slam', Novak Djokovic signe une vraie page d'histoire |url=http://www.eurosport.fr/tennis/roland-garros/2016/avec-le-nole-slam-novak-djokovic-signe-une-vraie-page-d-histoire_sto5636346/story.shtml |access-date=13 June 2016 |publisher=[[Eurosport]]}} With his French Open triumph, Djokovic became the eighth player in history to achieve a [[Grand Slam (tennis)#Career Grand Slam|Career Grand Slam]], the third player in history after [[Don Budge]] and [[Rod Laver]] to hold all four Grand Slam titles at the same time, and the first player to win $100 million in prize money.{{cite web |last1=Meiseles |first1=Josh |date=5 June 2016 |title=Djokovic Outlasts Murray For Historic Roland Garros Crown |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/roland-garros-final-2016-djokovic-murray |access-date=5 June 2016 |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]}} The victory at Roland Garros brought his ATP ranking points up to a new record of 16,950.{{Cite web |last=Arjun |title=7 Novak Djokovic records which may never be broken |url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/tennis/5-novak-djokovic-achievements-which-may-never-be-surpassed-ss |access-date=9 September 2022 |website=www.sportskeeda.com |language=en-us}}{{Cite web |title=Nole sets new absolute ATP ranking record! |url=https://novakdjokovic.com/en/news/tennis/nole-sets-new-absolute-atp-ranking-record/ |access-date=9 September 2022 |website=novakdjokovic.com |language=en-US}} At [[2016 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|Wimbledon]], his major win streak came to an end in the third-round when he lost to American [[Sam Querrey]] in four sets. It was his earliest exit in a Grand Slam since the [[2009 French Open – Men's singles|2009 French Open]].{{cite news |last1=McCarvel |first1=Nick |date=2 July 2016 |title=Novak Djokovic upset by American Sam Querrey at Wimbledon |work=[[USA Today]] |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/tennis/2016/07/02/novak-djokovic-upset-american-sam-querrey-wimbledon/86634092/ |access-date=2 July 2016}} In late July, Djokovic returned to form by winning his fourth [[2016 Rogers Cup – Men's singles|Rogers Cup]] title, and 30th Masters title overall, without dropping a set.{{cite news |title=How The Toronto Final Was Won: Djokovic Takes Title |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/toronto-2016-final-set-by-set-djokovic-nishikori |access-date=1 August 2016 |publisher=atpworldtour.com |date=31 July 2016}} In August, Djokovic was beaten in the first round of the [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's singles|Olympic men's singles]] in Rio de Janeiro by [[Juan Martín del Potro]]. It was Djokovic's first opening round defeat since January 2009, when [[Ernest Gulbis]] defeated him at the [[2009 Brisbane International – Men's singles|2009 Brisbane International]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/37007510 |title=Rio Olympics 2016: Novak Djokovic beaten by Juan Martín del Potro in first round |date=8 August 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=9 August 2016}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/olympics/2016/08/08/rio-olympics-2016-novak-djokovic-crashes-out-of-the-tennis-at-th/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220110/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/olympics/2016/08/08/rio-olympics-2016-novak-djokovic-crashes-out-of-the-tennis-at-th/ |archive-date=10 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |title=Novak Djokovic cries on the court after losing to Juan Martín Del Potro at Rio Olympics 2016 |date=8 August 2016 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |access-date=10 August 2016}}{{cbignore}} In the final slam of the year, the [[2016 US Open – Men's singles|US Open]], Djokovic advanced to the final but was defeated by [[Stan Wawrinka]] in four sets.{{cite news |title=Stan Reigns in New York: How The US Open Final Was Won |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/us-open-2016-final-set-by-set-djokovic-wawrinka |access-date=12 September 2016 |publisher=atpworldtour.com |date=11 September 2016}} Djokovic was defeated by [[Roberto Bautista Agut]] and [[Marin Čilić]] in the semi-finals and quarterfinals of [[2016 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles|Shanghai]] and [[2016 BNP Paribas Masters – Singles|Paris]]. Due to this result, he lost the No. 1 ranking to [[Andy Murray]].{{cite news |title=Djokovic: If Murray Gets To No. 1, He Deserves It |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-reaction-paris-2016-friday |access-date=7 November 2016 |publisher=atpworldtour.com |date=4 November 2016}} However, a runner-up finish at the [[2016 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles|ATP Finals]] indicated his best performances in nearly three months. After the season, he parted ways with his coach of three years, [[Boris Becker]].{{cite news |title=Novak Djokovic splits with coach Boris Becker after three years |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/dec/06/novak-djokovic-splits-with-coach-boris-becker-after-three-years |access-date=12 July 2017 |work=The Guardian |date=6 December 2016}} ==== 2017: Split with team and long injury hiatus ==== {{Main|2017 Novak Djokovic tennis season}} In January, Djokovic defended his title in [[2017 Qatar ExxonMobil Open|Doha]] after defeating the new world No. 1 [[Andy Murray]]. At the [[2017 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]], he was upset in the second round by world No. 117 [[Denis Istomin]]. This was the first time since [[2007 Australian Open – Men's singles|2007]] that Djokovic failed to reach the quarterfinals at the Australian Open, and the first time in his career that he lost to a player ranked outside of the top 100 at a major.{{cite web |url=http://mondo.rs/a974587/Sport/Tenis/Novak-Djokovic-Denis-Istomin-Australijan-Open.html |title=SENZACIJA: Ispao Novak Đoković! |publisher=mondo.rs |date=19 January 2017 |access-date=25 January 2017}} In February and March, Djokovic played at the [[2017 Abierto Mexicano Telcel – Men's singles|Mexican Open]] and [[2017 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|Indian Wells Masters]], but was eliminated by [[Nick Kyrgios]] in both events before the semifinals. In April, Djokovic reached the quarterfinals of the [[2017 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles|Monte-Carlo Masters]], losing to [[David Goffin]]. After the tournament, he chose to split with his long-time coach [[Marián Vajda]], fitness specialist [[Gebhard Phil-Gritsch]], and physiotherapist Miljan Amanović, citing the need to find a winning spark. A better showing at the [[2017 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles|Madrid Masters]] saw Djokovic reach the semifinals, losing to Nadal in straight sets.{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/madrid-2017-saturday-djokovic-nadal-set-by-set |title=Nadal Claims Emphatic Win To Book Madrid Final |publisher=atptour.com |date=13 May 2017 |access-date=15 November 2020}} A runner-up result at the [[2017 Italian Open – Men's singles|Rome Masters]] indicated improvement in his form. On 21 May 2017, Djokovic announced that [[Andre Agassi]] would become his new coach, starting at the [[2017 French Open – Men's singles|2017 French Open]]. However, as the defending champion, he lost in the quarterfinals to [[Dominic Thiem]].{{cite news |title=Thiem Takes Out Defending Champ Djokovic |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-thiem-roland-garros-2017-wednesday |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals|ATP]] |date=7 June 2017}} He began the grass court season at the [[2017 Aegon International Eastbourne – Men's singles|Eastbourne International]], playing his first non-Wimbledon tournament on grass since [[2010 Aegon Championships – Singles|2010]]. He won the title by beating [[Gaël Monfils]] in the final. He made it to the quarterfinals at [[2017 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|Wimbledon]] before retiring against [[Tomáš Berdych]] due to an elbow injury.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/tennis/wimb/2017/07/12/novak-djokovic-retires-wimbledon/472377001/ |title=Novak Djokovic retires from Wimbledon quarterfinal match with injury |work=USA Today |date=12 July 2017 |access-date=13 July 2017}} On 26 July, Djokovic announced he would miss the [[2017 US Open – Men's singles|US Open]] and the rest of the 2017 season to recover from his elbow injury.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/jul/26/novak-djokovic-miss-2017-season-injury |title=Novak Djokovic will miss the rest of 2017 season with elbow injury |work=The Guardian |date=16 July 2017 |access-date=26 July 2017}} ==== 2018: Surgery and resurgence; two Major titles, return to No. 1, and historic Career Golden Masters ==== {{Main|2018 Novak Djokovic tennis season}} In January, Djokovic defeated [[Dominic Thiem]] at the [[Kooyong Classic]] exhibition tournament. At the [[2018 Australian Open – Men's singles|2018 Australian Open]], he reached the fourth round, where he was upset by [[Chung Hyeon]]. In late January, he underwent surgery on his elbow.{{Cite news |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-tennis-djokovic-idUKKBN1FN0H6 |title=Djokovic undergoes surgery to cure troublesome elbow |newspaper=Reuters |date=3 February 2018 |via=uk.reuters.com}} On 3 March, Djokovic returned to the practice courts,{{Cite web |url=https://twitter.com/DjokerNole/statuses/970044980390641664 |title=DjokerNole Twitter |access-date=5 June 2018}} and surprisingly played at [[2018 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|Indian Wells]] only a week later, losing in the second round to [[Taro Daniel]].{{cite web |title=In Indian Wells Defeat, Novak Djokovic Shows Just How Far He Has To Go |url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2018/03/novak-djokovic-upset-qualifier-taro-daniel-indian-wells/72654/ |website=Tennis.com |publisher=Tennis.com |access-date=5 June 2018}} He then lost to [[Benoît Paire]] in the second round of the [[2018 Miami Open – Men's singles|Miami Open]].{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic loses to Benoit Paire at Miami Open |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/tennis/story/_/id/22887538/6-champion-novak-djokovic-loses-miami-open-benoit-paire |website=ESPN |date=23 March 2018 |publisher=ESPN |access-date=5 June 2018}} Reuniting with longtime coach [[Marián Vajda]] at the [[2018 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles|Monte Carlo Masters]], Djokovic collected victories over [[Dušan Lajović]] and [[Borna Ćorić]], followed by a loss to Dominic Thiem. In a press conference, he stated, "After two years finally I can play without pain."{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-monte-carlo-2018-monday-reaction |title=Djokovic Monte Carlo 2018 |website=atpworldtour.com |publisher=ATP |access-date=5 June 2018}} After another early exit in [[2018 Barcelona Open Banco Sabadell – Singles|Barcelona]] to [[Martin Kližan]],{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic's woes worsen with defeat by qualifier at Barcelona Open |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/apr/25/novak-djokovic-woes-worsen-defeat-to-qualifier-martin-klizan-barcelona-open-tennis |work=The Guardian |date=25 April 2018 |access-date=5 June 2018}} Djokovic's gradual return to form would appear at the [[2018 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles|Madrid Masters]]. With a first round win over [[Kei Nishikori]], Djokovic achieved his first victory over a top 20 player in 10 months; however, he lost in the second round to [[Kyle Edmund]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/44033242 |title=Madrid Open: Novak Djokovic beats Kei Nishikori in round one |date=7 May 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=14 May 2018}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/44056857 |title=Madrid Open: Britain's Kyle Edmund beats Novak Djokovic |date=9 May 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=14 May 2018}} Going into the [[2018 Italian Open – Men's singles|Rome Masters]] with a 6–6 season record, he reached the semifinals before losing to long-time rival [[Rafael Nadal]].{{cite news |title=Novak Djokovic produces best performance of the year but is outlasted by Rafael Nadal in Rome |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tennis/2018/05/19/novak-djokovic-produces-best-performance-year-outlasted-rafael/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220110/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tennis/2018/05/19/novak-djokovic-produces-best-performance-year-outlasted-rafael/ |archive-date=10 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |website=The Telegraph |date=19 May 2018 |publisher=The Telegraph |access-date=5 June 2018 |last1=Eccleshare |first1=Charlie}}{{cbignore}} He then reached the quarterfinals of the [[2018 French Open – Men's singles|French Open]] before losing to [[Marco Cecchinato]].{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic loses to Marco Cecchinato in stunning French Open quarter-final upset |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/french-open-men/2018/novak-djokovic-loses-to-marco-cecchinato-in-stunning-french-open-quarter-final-upset_sto6793173/story.shtml |website=Eurosport |date=5 June 2018 |publisher=Eurosport |access-date=5 June 2018}} [[File:Novak Djokovic (40021939483).jpg|thumb|250px|Djokovic celebrating at the [[2018 US Open – Men's singles|2018 US Open]]]] Djokovic began the grass court season at [[2018 Queen's Club Championships – Singles|Queen's Club]], securing his first win over a top 5 player in almost 18 months by defeating [[Grigor Dimitrov]] in the second round. He reached the final where, despite holding a championship point, he lost to [[Marin Čilić]].{{cite web |title=Wimbledon 2018: Marin Cilic beats Novak Djokovic in close final to claim second Queen's title |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/wimbledon-2018-marin-cilic-vs-novak-djokovic-queens-final-report-highlights-a8414821.html |website=Independent |date=24 June 2018 |publisher=Independent |access-date=16 July 2018}} He also played doubles partnering with longtime friend and rival [[Stan Wawrinka]]. Djokovic then entered [[2018 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|Wimbledon]] as the 12th seed, where he reached the semifinals to face Rafael Nadal. Djokovic defeated Nadal in a 5-hour and 17-minute, five-set match spread over two days.{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic outlasts Rafael Nadal in epic Wimbledon semi-final |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/jul/14/novak-djokovic-rafael-nadal-wimbledon-semi-final |work=The Guardian |date=14 July 2018 |access-date=16 July 2018}} In the final, he claimed his fourth Wimbledon title and 13th major title overall by defeating [[Kevin Anderson (tennis)|Kevin Anderson]] in straight sets. With the win, he rose 11 ranking spots and re-entered the top 10 for the first time since October 2017.{{cite news |title=Novak Djokovic wins fourth Wimbledon by beating Kevin Anderson |publisher=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/44839313 |access-date=15 July 2018}} After a triumphant grass season, Djokovic started his North American hardcourt swing with a third-round showing at the [[2018 Rogers Cup – Men's singles|Rogers Cup]], losing to [[Stefanos Tsitsipas]]. Afterwards, he returned to play the [[2018 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles|Cincinnati Masters]] for the first time in three years. In an event plagued by suspended play due to rain, Djokovic defeated the defending champion Grigor Dimitrov, [[Milos Raonic]], and Marin Čilić to reach his sixth final at the tournament and fourth final against [[Roger Federer]]. Although Federer was riding a streak of 100 consecutive holds of serve at the tournament,{{cite news |title=Roger Federer v Novak Djokovic: Cincinnati Masters men's final – live! |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/live/2018/aug/19/cincinnati-open-mens-final-roger-federer-novak-djokovic-latest-score |newspaper=The Guardian |date=19 August 2018 |access-date=19 August 2018 |last1=Lutz |first1=Tom}} Djokovic broke his serve three times to win his first Cincinnati Masters title. With this victory, Djokovic became the first (and, as of 2022, only) player in tennis history to complete the [[Tennis Masters Series singles records and statistics#Career Golden Masters|Career Golden Masters]] — winning all nine ATP Masters events at least once in one's career.{{cite web |title=NOVAK DJOKOVIC IS A WIN AWAY FROM MAKING MASTERS HISTORY IN CINCINNATI |url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2018/08/novak-djokovic-marin-cilic-cincinnati-masters-1000-atp/76112/ |website=Tennis.com |publisher=Tennis.com |access-date=19 August 2018}} Djokovic was the sixth seed at the [[2018 US Open – Men's singles|US Open]]. He advanced to his eleventh US Open semifinal in as many appearances, where he overcame Kei Nishikori. Djokovic then defeated [[Juan Martín del Potro]] to win his third US Open title and 14th major title overall, tying [[Pete Sampras]]' tally. With the win, Djokovic returned to the top 3 in the world rankings for the first time since the 2017 French Open.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/sep/09/novak-djokovic-juan-martin-del-potro-us-open-mens-final-match-report |title=Novak Djokovic powers past Juan Martín del Potro to win third US Open |date=10 September 2018 |work=The Guardian |access-date=10 September 2018}} At the [[2018 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles|Shanghai Masters]], Djokovic defeated Kevin Anderson and [[Alexander Zverev]] en route to the title, not dropping a set nor having his serve broken throughout. The win marked his fourth Shanghai title, and his ranking rose to No. 2.{{cite web |url=https://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-coric-shanghai-2018-final-sunday |title=Read & Watch: Djokovic Wins Record Fourth Shanghai Title, 32nd Masters 1000 Crown |date=14 October 2018 |work=ATP World Tour |access-date=14 October 2018 |archive-date=15 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181015163507/https://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/djokovic-coric-shanghai-2018-final-sunday |url-status=dead}} On 31 October, Rafael Nadal announced his withdrawal from the Paris Masters due to an abdominal injury, and Djokovic reclaimed the world No. 1 ranking.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/46042799 |title=Paris Masters: Rafael Nadal out with injury & Roger Federer through |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 October 2018 |access-date=2 November 2018}} There, Djokovic defeated Roger Federer in a tight three-set semifinal, but was upset by the unseeded [[Karen Khachanov]] in the final.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/live/2018/nov/04/karen-khachanov-v-novak-djokovic-paris-masters-tennis-live |title=Paris Masters final: Karen Khachanov beats Novak Djokovic– as it happened |work=The Guardian |date=4 November 2018 |access-date=12 November 2018}} At the [[2018 ATP Finals – Singles|ATP Finals]], Djokovic was guaranteed a fifth year-end No. 1 ranking following the withdrawal of Rafael Nadal from the event. In the round-robin stage, he defeated Alexander Zverev, Marin Čilić, and [[John Isner]] without dropping a set. In the semifinals, he defeated Kevin Anderson to reach his seventh final at the tournament but was upset by Zverev.{{cite web |url=https://www.atpworldtour.com/en/news/london-finale-2018-preview-djokovic-zverev |title=Djokovic, Zverev Set Championship Clash In London |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] |date=18 November 2018 |access-date=19 November 2018}} At the [[2018 Mubadala World Tennis Championship|2018 Mubadala Championship]], he scored victories over Karen Khachanov & Kevin Anderson to win the title. ====2019: Historic 7th Australian Open title and 5th Wimbledon title==== {{Main|2019 Novak Djokovic tennis season}} [[File:Novak Djokovic (49745016006).jpg|thumb|250px|Djokovic kissing Wimbledon trophy after winning the 2019 [[2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|Wimbledon Championships]].]] Djokovic's first tournament of the year was at the [[2019 Qatar ExxonMobil Open – Singles|Qatar Open]], where he lost to [[Roberto Bautista Agut]] in the semifinals. He then entered the [[2019 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]] as the top seed, and defeated [[Rafael Nadal]] in the final to win his record seventh Australian Open and 15th [[Grand Slam (tennis)#Tournaments|major]] title overall.{{cite news |title=Australian Open 2019: Novak Djokovic beats Rafael Nadal to win record seventh title |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/47019140 |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=28 January 2019}} Djokovic then played at the [[2019 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|Indian Wells Masters]], where he was upset by [[Philipp Kohlschreiber]] in the third round,{{cite news |title=Indian Wells: Novak Djokovic beaten by Philipp Kohlschreiber in third round |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/47548791 |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=17 March 2019}} and lost in the fourth round of the [[2019 Miami Open – Men's singles|Miami Open]] to Bautista Agut.{{cite news |title=Miami Open: Novak Djokovic & Kyle Edmund lose in fourth round |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/47711551 |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=1 April 2019}} Djokovic then began his clay court season at the [[2019 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles|Monte Carlo Masters]], losing in the quarterfinals to [[Daniil Medvedev]].{{cite news |title=Monte Carlo Masters: Novak Djokovic loses to Daniil Medvedev, Rafael Nadal into semi-finals |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/47991727 |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=23 April 2019}} During the [[2019 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles|Madrid Open]], Novak Djokovic celebrated his 250th week at [[List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players|world number 1]] in [[ATP rankings]].{{cite web |title=Djokovic Celebrates 250 Weeks At No. 1 In ATP Rankings |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-celebrates-250th-week-at-no-1-in-atp-rankings |website=ATP Tour |publisher=ATP Tour |access-date=6 May 2019}} By beating [[Stefanos Tsitsipas]] in the final, Djokovic claimed his third Madrid Open title and record-equaling 33rd ATP Masters title overall.{{cite web |title=Djokovic Beats Tsitsipas For Madrid Title, Tying Nadal's Masters 1000 Record |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-tsitsipas-madrid-2019-final |website=ATP Tour |publisher=ATP Tour |access-date=13 May 2019}} At the [[2019 Italian Open – Men's singles|Italian Open]], he reached the final after a brutal victory over long time rival [[Juan Martín del Potro]],{{cite web |title=Djokovic beats Del Potro in three-set thriller in Rome |url=https://www.eurosport.co.uk/tennis/rome-masters/2019/novak-djokovic-beats-juan-martin-del-potro-in-rome_sto7277844/story.shtml |website=eurosport.co.uk |date=18 May 2019 |publisher=[[Eurosport]] |access-date=18 May 2019}} where he lost to Rafael Nadal.{{cite news |title=Nadal Beats Djokovic To Win Ninth Rome Title |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-nadal-rome-2019-final |access-date=19 May 2019 |publisher=atptour.com |date=19 May 2019}} Djokovic competed in the [[2019 French Open – Men's singles|French Open]], reaching the semifinals without dropping a set. His fourth-round win made him the first man to reach 10 consecutive quarterfinals at Roland Garros. In the semifinals, he lost to [[Dominic Thiem]] in a four-hour, five-set match stretched across two days, ending his 26-match winning streak in majors and his search for a second 'Nole Slam".{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2019/jun/08/dominic-thiem-novak-djokovic-french-open-semi-final-report |title=Dominic Thiem ends Novak Djokovic's slam streak to reach French Open final |last=Cambers |first=Simon |date=8 June 2019 |work=The Observer |access-date=8 June 2019 |issn=0029-7712}} At [[2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|Wimbledon]], Djokovic defended his title to win his fifth Wimbledon title and 16th major title overall, defeating [[Roger Federer]] in an epic five-set [[2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final|final]] that lasted a record four hours and fifty-seven minutes. Djokovic, who won fewer points overall than Federer, saved two championship points in the fifth set to win the title.{{cite news |title=Novak Djokovic Wins Wimbledon |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/14/sports/tennis/federer-vs-djokovic.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190714181512/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/14/sports/tennis/federer-vs-djokovic.html |archive-date=14 July 2019 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |access-date=14 July 2019 |work=The New York Times |date=14 July 2019}}{{cite news |title=Djokovic tops Federer in epic Wimbledon final |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/27189215/djokovic-tops-federer-epic-wimbledon-final |access-date=14 July 2019 |work=espn.com |date=14 July 2019}} Djokovic next played at the [[2019 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles|Cincinnati Open]] as the defending champion, but lost to eventual champion Daniil Medvedev in the semifinals.{{cite web |title=Daniil Medvedev stuns Novak Djokovic to set up Cincinnati final with Goffin |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2019/aug/18/tennis-daniil-medvedev-stuns-novak-djokovic-cincinnati-semi-final-david-goffin |work=The Guardian |date=18 August 2015).{{cite news |title=Roger Federer beats Novak Djokovic at 2019 ATP Finals in London |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/50423549 |publisher=BBC Sport |access-date=17 November 2019}} ===2020s=== ====2020: ATP Cup crown, 8th Australian Open title, and the double Golden Masters==== {{Main|2020 Novak Djokovic tennis season}} At the inaugural [[2020 ATP Cup]], Djokovic led Serbia to the title by scoring six victories, including wins over [[Daniil Medvedev]] in the semifinals and [[Rafael Nadal]] in the final.{{cite web |title=Serbia wins atp cup |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-01-13/serbia-wins-atp-cup-nadal-upset-wth-football-crowd/11861792 |website=abc.net.au |date=12 January 2020 |publisher=ABC news |access-date=13 January 2020}} At the [[2020 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]], he defeated [[Djokovic–Federer rivalry|longtime rival]] [[Roger Federer]] in straight sets en route to the final where he overcame [[Dominic Thiem]] in five sets. Sports |date=18 May 2022 |access-date=5 December 2022}} Djokovic entered the [[2022 Dubai Tennis Championships – Men's singles|Dubai Championships]] in February, where vaccination was not required for entry.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/60157577 |title=Novak Djokovic set for return to action in Dubai after missing Australian Open |publisher=BBC News |date=27 January 2022 |access-date=30 January 2022}} He was upset in the quarterfinals by [[Jiří Veselý]], resulting in him conceding his [[List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players|world No. 1]] ranking to [[Daniil Medvedev]]. This marked the first time a man outside of the [[Big Four (tennis)|Big Four]] was ranked singles world No. 1 since [[Andy Roddick]] in February 2004.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/60512757 |title=Novak Djokovic to lose number one ranking after defeat to Jiri Vesely in Dubai |work=[[BBC News]] |date=24 February 2022 |access-date=24 February 2022}} Djokovic withdrew from both the [[2022 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|Indian Wells Masters]] and the [[2022 Miami Open – Men's singles|Miami Open]], due to the United States [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|forbidding unvaccinated foreign travellers]].{{cite news |last1=Carayol |first1=Tumaini |title=Novak Djokovic pulls out of Indian Wells as vaccine stance derails US trip |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/mar/10/novak-djokovic-pulls-out-of-indian-wells-as-vaccine-stance-puts-paid-to-us-trip |access-date=20 March 2022 |work=The Guardian |date=9 March 2022}} Despite being unable to play, Djokovic regained the world No. 1 ranking after Medvedev's third-round defeat at Indian Wells.{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/tennis/news/12110/12566488/indian-wells-daniil-medvedev-loses-no-1-spot-to-novak-djokovic-after-third-round-defeat |title=Indian Wells: Daniil Medvedev loses No 1 spot to Novak Djokovic after third-round defeat |work=Sky News |date=14 March 2022 |access-date=15 March 2022}} After being unable to play in March, Djokovic began his clay court season at the [[2022 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles|Monte-Carlo Masters]] in April, seeded first. Sport Australia |url=https://au.sports.yahoo.com/tennis-2022-novak-djokovic-career-first-monte-carlo-204323111.html |access-date=12 April 2022}} In April, he made it to the final of the [[2022 Serbia Open – Singles|Serbia Open]], but lost to [[Andrey Rublev]] in three sets.{{cite news |title=Novak Djokovic loses to Andrey Rublev in Serbia Open final |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/apr/24/novak-djokovic-beaten-by-andrey-rublev-in-serbia-open-final |access-date=24 April 2022 |work=The Guardian |agency=PA Media |date=24 April 2022}} At the [[2022 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles|Madrid Open]] in May, Djokovic made it to the semifinals where he was beaten by 19 year old and eventual champion [[Carlos Alcaraz]].{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-madrid-2022-reaction-saturday |title=Djokovic Praises Alcaraz Following Madrid Defeat |publisher=ATP Tour |date=7 May 2022}} At the [[2022 Italian Open – Men's singles|Italian Open]] a week later, he reached the twelfth final of his career at this Masters. In the semifinals, he defeated [[Casper Ruud]] for his 1,000th career win, becoming only the fifth man in the Open Era to reach this milestone.{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-ruud-rome-2022-sf |title=Novak Djokovic Scores 1,000th Career Win to Reach Rome Final |publisher=ATP Tour}} In the final, he defeated [[Stefanos Tsitsipas]] to win his sixth [[Italian Open (tennis)|Italian Open]] and 38th Masters title.{{Cite web |date=15 May 2022 |title=Djokovic enters French defense with Italian title |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/33921941/novak-djokovic-sweeps-every-set-en-route-italian-open-title |access-date=15 May 2022 |website=ESPN}} Djokovic entered the [[2022 French Open - Men's Singles|French Open]] in May as the defending champion. After defeating [[Yoshihito Nishioka]], [[Alex Molčan]], [[Aljaž Bedene]] and [[Diego Schwartzman]] in straight sets, he faced [[Rafael Nadal]] in the quarterfinals for their [[Djokovic–Nadal rivalry|record-extending 59th meeting]]. He lost in four sets, ending his French Open title defense.{{cite web |title=Nadal Downs Djokovic In Classic Roland Garros QF |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-nadal-roland-garros-2022-qf |publisher=ATP Tour |access-date=9 June 2022}} As a result of his quarterfinals defeat, he conceded the No. 1 ranking to [[Daniil Medvedev]] for the second time in 2022. Slams.{{cite web |url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/tennis/news-novak-djokovic-becomes-first-player-history-win-80-matches-grand-slams-1r-win-2022-wimbledon |title=Novak Djokovic becomes the first He won his 90th singles trophy defeating [[Stefanos Tsitsipas]] in the final.{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-tsitsipas-astana-2022-final |title=Novak Djokovic Defeats Stefanos Tsitsipas, Triumphs in Astana |publisher=ATP Tour |date=9 October 2022}} Djokovic also qualified for the [[2022 ATP Finals]] for the 15th time by winning the open.{{cite web |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/stat-of-the-day-novak-djokovic-qualifies-for-atp-finals-for-15th-time |title=Stat of the Day: Novak Djokovic qualifies for ATP Finals for 15th time after winning Astana |website=tennis.com |last=Berkok |first=John |date=9 October 2022}}{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-nitto-atp-finals-2022-qualification |title=Novak Djokovic Earns 15th Nitto ATP Finals Qualification |publisher=ATP Tour |date=9 October 2022}} At his next tournament the [[2022 Rolex Paris Masters]], he reached his 90th Masters quarterfinal defeating [[Karen Khachanov]], who was the only player to defeat him in the final of this Masters.{{cite tweet |url=https://twitter.com/ATPMediaInfo/status/1588232638787207171 |title=6-time champion @DjokerNole defeats Karen Khachanov, the only man to beat him in a #RolexParisMasters final, 6-4 6-1 to reach his 90th #ATPMasters1000 QF. |number=1588232638787207171 |user=ATPMediaInfo |author=ATP Media Info |date=3 November 2022 |access-date=5 December 2022}} He powered into his 74th Masters 1000 semifinal and eight at this tournament with a straight sets win over [[Lorenzo Musetti]].{{cite tweet |url=https://twitter.com/atptour/status/1588621404072648704 |title=Red-hot Nole 💥 |user=atptour |author=ATP Tour |number=1588621404072648704 |date=4 November 2022 |access-date=5 December 2022}} He reached his third straight final for the season and eight overall at this Masters defeating Stefanos Tsitsipas. Dane Stuns Novak Djokovic |publisher=ATP Tour |date=6 November 2022}} Seeded seventh at the [[2022 ATP Finals]] Djokovic won his first round robin match over second seed Stefanos Tsitsipas recording his 60th win over top-3 players, making him the first man to accomplish this milestone since the ATP rankings begin in 1973. three different decades—the 2000s, 2010s and 2020s.{{cite web | url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/novak-djokovic-wins-record-tying-sixth-atp-finals-title-casper-ruud-turin | title=Novak 2023 ==== {{main|2023 Novak Djokovic tennis season}} ==Rivalries== {{see also|Big Three (tennis)|List of tennis rivalries}} === Rafael Nadal === {{Main|Djokovic–Nadal rivalry}} Djokovic and [[Rafael Nadal]] have met 59 times, including in all four Grand Slam finals, an Open-Era record for head-to-head meetings between male players;{{cite web |last=Sharko |first=Greg |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2011/09/Features/Shark-Bites-Djokovic-US-Open.aspx |title=Shark Bites – Djokovic's $10m Season |publisher=ATP World Tour |date=13 September 2011 |access-date=29 October 2011}} Djokovic leads 30–29.{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2015/04/15/Monte-Carlo-Saturday-Nadal-Djokovic.aspx |title=ATP World Tour: Novak Claims Blockbuster |access-date=18 April 2015}}{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic VS Rafael Nadal |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/players/fedex-head-2-head/novak-djokovic-vs-rafael-nadal/D643/N409 |website=ATP World Tour |publisher=ATP World Tour |access-date=11 April 2018}} Djokovic leads on hard courts 20–7, while Nadal leads on clay 20–8, and they are tied on grass 2–2.{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/Players/Head-To-Head.aspx?pId=N409&oId=D643 |title=FEDEX ATP HEAD 2 HEADs |access-date=19 August 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819042249/http://www.atpworldtour.com/Players/Head-To-Head.aspx?pId=N409&oId=D643 |archive-date=19 August 2011}} They have played a record 18 Grand Slam matches, with Nadal winning 11, and a joint-record nine Grand Slam tournament finals (tied with [[Federer–Nadal rivalry|Federer–Nadal]]) with Nadal winning five. Djokovic is the first player to have at least ten match wins against Nadal and the only person to defeat Nadal seven times consecutively (which he did twice).{{cite web |url=http://studentbounty.com/essays/novak-djokovic/8/ |title=Student Bounty Essays |access-date=20 September 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151122111247/http://studentbounty.com/essays/novak-djokovic/8/ |archive-date=22 November 2015 |url-status=dead}} The two share the record for the longest Grand Slam final match ever played (5 hours and 53 minutes), at the 2012 Australian Open final.{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2012/01/4/Australian-Open-Sunday-Djokovic-Nadal-Final.aspx |title=Australian Open 2012 Sunday – Djokovic Wins Epic Contest to Retain Melbourne Title |publisher=ATP World Tour |access-date=20 April 2012}} ===Roger Federer=== {{Main|Djokovic–Federer rivalry}} [[File:Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer at USO 2011 (cropped).jpg|300px|thumb|Djokovic and Federer after their semifinal match at the [[2011 US Open – Men's singles|2011 US Open]].]] Djokovic played Federer in his first Major final at the [[2007 US Open – Men's singles|2007 US Open]] and lost in three sets.{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/usopen07/news/story?id=3012146 |title=Federer grabs fourth straight U.S. Open win, 12th career major title |publisher=ESPN |date=10 September 2007 |access-date=29 October 2011}} They met 50 times (not including [[2014 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles|one occasion]] when there was a [[Glossary of tennis terms#walkover|walkover]] in favour of Djokovic). Djokovic has 27 wins to Federer's 23. He leads on hard courts 20–18 as well as on grass 3–1; they are split 4–4 on clay.{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic VS Roger Federer |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/players/fedex-head-2-head/novak-djokovic-vs-roger-federer/D643/F324 |website=ATP World Tour |publisher=ATP World Tour |access-date=11 April 2018}} Djokovic had more wins against [[Roger Federer]] than any other player. They have played 17 Grand Slam matches. Djokovic is the only player other than Nadal who has defeated Federer in consecutive Grand Slam tournament matches.{{cite web |title=Roger Federer vs. Novak Ðoković Australian Open Preview |url=http://www.tennis-x.com/story/2008-01-24/h.php |access-date=24 January 2008}} Federer ended Djokovic's 41-match winning start to the 2011 season at the [[2011 French Open – Men's singles|2011 French Open]] semi-finals.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/tennis/frenchopen/8556037/French-Open-2011-Roger-Federer-destroys-Novak-Djokovics-run-of-victories-to-surge-into-final.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220110/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/tennis/frenchopen/8556037/French-Open-2011-Roger-Federer-destroys-Novak-Djokovics-run-of-victories-to-surge-into-final.html |archive-date=10 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |title=French Open 2011: Roger Federer destroys Novak Djokovic's run of victories to surge into final |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=3 June 2011 |access-date=29 October 2011 |location=London, UK |first=Ian |last=Chadband}}{{cbignore}} However, Federer lost to Djokovic in straight sets the following year.{{cite news |url=http://www.emirates247.com/sports/tennis/djokovic-crushes-federer-to-set-up-nadal-final-2012-06-09-1.462173 |title=French Open 2012: Djokovic crushes Federer to set up Nadal Final |publisher=emirates247 |date=9 June 2012 |access-date=20 June 2012}} Federer's last major [[2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final|final]] was against Djokovic at the [[2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|2019 Wimbledon Championships]]. Djokovic won in five sets with the final set going to a tiebreak, in what became the longest final in Wimbledon history. Notably, Djokovic won despite Federer statistically outplaying him in all categories except unforced errors and tiebreaks won.{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tennis-wimbledon-federer-idUSKCN1UA00F |title=Federer does everything right but falls short on match points |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=15 July 2019 |access-date=2 October 2022}} Their final encounter was at the semifinals of the [[2020 Australian Open – Men's singles|2020 Australian Open]]; Djokovic won in straight sets. ===Andy Murray=== {{Main|Djokovic–Murray rivalry}} Djokovic and [[Andy Murray]] have met 36 times, with Djokovic leading 25–11.{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic VS Andy Murray |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/players/fedex-head-2-head/novak-djokovic-vs-andy-murray/D643/MC10 |website=ATP World Tour |publisher=ATP World Tour |access-date=11 April 2018}} Djokovic leads 5–1 on clay, 20–8 on hard courts, and Murray leads 2–0 on grass. The two are almost exactly the same age, with Murray being a week older than Djokovic. They went to training camp together, and Murray won the first match they ever played as teenagers. The pair have met 19 times in finals, which Djokovic leads 11–8. Ten of the finals were Masters finals, where they are tied at 5–5. Their most notable match in this category was a three-set thriller at the final of the [[2012 Shanghai Rolex Masters|2012 Shanghai Masters]], in which Murray held five championship point opportunities in the second set; however, Djokovic saved each of them, forcing a deciding set.{{cite web |url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/2012-10-14/djokovic-masters-murray-in-shanghai/1030224 |title=Djokovic masters Murray in Shanghai |publisher=radioaustralia.net.au |date=14 October 2012}} He eventually prevailed to win his first Shanghai Masters title, ending Murray's 12–0 winning streak at the event. This, and the three-set match they played in [[2011 Italian Open – Men's singles|Rome in 2011]], were voted the ATP Tour match of the Year, for each respective season.{{cite web |title=The 2 Best ATP World Tour matches of 2011 |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2011/12/Features/Best-ATP-Matches-Of-2011.aspx |publisher=ATP |access-date=5 February 2013}}{{cite web |title=Best ATP World Tour matches of the Year – Nos. 1–2 |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2012/11/Features/Best-ATP-Matches-Of-2012.aspx |publisher=ATP |access-date=5 February 2013}} They have also met in seven Grand Slam tournament finals. ===Stan Wawrinka=== Djokovic and [[Stan Wawrinka]] have met 26 times with Djokovic leading 20–6. However, the two have contested numerous close matches, including four five-setters at the Grand Slam tournaments.{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic VS Stan Wawrinka |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/players/fedex-head-2-head/novak-djokovic-vs-stan-wawrinka/D643/W367 |website=ATP World Tour |publisher=ATP World Tour |access-date=11 April 2018}} Wawrinka and Djokovic have played three consecutive Australian Opens – each match going to five sets – and a five-setter in the US Open. In the [[2013 Australian Open – Men's singles|2013 Australian Open]] fourth round, Djokovic won 12–10 in a fifth set; at the [[2013 US Open – Men's singles|2013 US Open]] semi-finals Djokovic won 6–4 in the fifth set; at the [[2014 Australian Open – Men's singles|2014 Australian Open]] quarterfinals, Wawrinka won 9–7 in the fifth. Wawrinka's win broke Djokovic's run of 14 consecutive semi-finals in Grand Slam play, and ended a 28-match winning streak.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/jan/21/novak-djokovic-stanislas-wawrinka-live-australian-open |title=Stanislas Wawrinka beats Novak Djokovic: as it happened |work=The Guardian |location=London, UK |access-date=12 February 2014}} Djokovic got revenge next year at the [[2015 Australian Open – Men's singles|2015 Australian Open]], winning 6–0 in the fifth set.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/live/2015/jan/30/australian-open-2015-novak-djokovic-v-stanislas-wawrinka-live |title=Novak Djokovic beats Stanislas Wawrinka to reach Australian Open final – as it happened |work=The Guardian |date=30 January 2015 |access-date=6 June 2015}} At the [[2015 French Open – Men's singles|2015 French Open]] final, Wawrinka defeated Djokovic in four sets to claim his second major title. Later that year, Djokovic beat Wawrinka at the [[2015 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles|Cincinnati Masters]] and [[2015 BNP Paribas Masters – Singles|Paris Masters]].{{cite web |url=http://www.stevegtennis.com/head-to-head/men/Novak_Djokovic/Stanislas_Wawrinka |title=Novak Djokovic vs Stan Wawrinka Head To Head |publisher=SteveGTennis.com |access-date=22 November 2015}} At the [[2016 US Open – Men's singles|2016 US Open]], Wawrinka beat Djokovic in a Grand Slam final for a second time. Djokovic was suffering from a foot injury in the latter stages of the match and lost in four sets. However, he attributed his loss to Wawrinka's courageous play at decisive moments in the match.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/12/sports/tennis/stan-wawrinka-stuns-top-seeded-novak-djokovic-in-us-open-final.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160912011740/http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/12/sports/tennis/stan-wawrinka-stuns-top-seeded-novak-djokovic-in-us-open-final.html |archive-date=12 September 2016 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |title=Stan Wawrinka Solves Top-Seeded Novak Djokovic to Win Third Major Title |work=The New York Times |date=11 September 2016 |access-date=16 September 2016}} Despite Djokovic's 20–6 overall record against Wawrinka, Wawrinka leads Djokovic 3–2 in [[Association of Tennis Professionals|ATP]] finals (2–0 in Grand Slams).{{cite web |url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/players/fedex-head-2-head/novak-djokovic-vs-stan-wawrinka/D643/W367 |title=NOVAK DJOKOVIC VS STAN WAWRINKA |publisher=atpworldtour.com |access-date=16 September 2016}} During Djokovic's run of thirteen appearances at Grand Slam finals from 2014 Wimbledon through the 2020 Australian Open, his only two losses were to Wawrinka. Contrary to most high-profile rivalries, they have played doubles together.{{cite news |date=30 September 2013 |title=Djokovic on playing doubles with Wawrinka in Beijing: I miss it |work=tennis.com |url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2013/09/djokovic-playing-doubles-wawrinka-beijing-i-miss-it/49318/ |access-date=12 September 2015}} ===Juan Martín del Potro=== Djokovic and [[Juan Martín del Potro]] have met 20 times, with Djokovic leading 16–4.{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic VS Juan Martin Del Potro |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/players/fedex-head-2-head/novak-djokovic-vs-juan-martin-del-potro/D643/D683 |website=ATP Tour |publisher=ATP Tour |access-date=29 January 2019}} Djokovic won their first four meetings, before back-to-back victories for del Potro at the 2011 Davis Cup and their Bronze medal match at the [[Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's singles|2012 Summer Olympics]] in straight sets. Djokovic won the next four matches before he loses again to del Potro at the [[2013 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|2013 Indian Wells Masters]] where the Argentinian made his second career Masters final. Djokovic got the upper hand on the rivalry once again by winning two of the most important matches between them to date; an epic five-setter at the [[2013 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|2013 Wimbledon Championships]] semifinals which was the longest Wimbledon semifinal at the time,{{cite web |title=Novak Djokovic beats Juan Martín del Potro in epic Wimbledon semi-final |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2013/jul/05/novak-djokovic-del-potro-wimbledon-semi |work=The Guardian |date=5 July 2013 |access-date=29 January 2019}} and a thrilling three-setter at the [[2013 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles|2013 Shanghai Masters]] final. Del Potro upset Djokovic in the first round at the [[2016 Summer Olympics|2016 Olympics]] in [[Rio de Janeiro|Rio]] en route to the final. In 2018, Djokovic defeated del Potro in three close sets in the final of the [[2018 US Open – Men's singles|US Open]], which was the first Grand Slam final for del Potro since his [[2009 US Open (tennis)|2009 US Open]] victory. They played their last match at the [[2019 Italian Open – Men's singles|2019 Italian Open]] quarterfinal which Djokovic won in a dramatic three-setter after he saved two match points. ===Jo-Wilfried Tsonga=== Djokovic and [[Jo-Wilfried Tsonga]] met 23 times, with Djokovic leading 17–6.{{cite web |url=http://tennis.wettpoint.com/en/h2h/91752-22227.html |title=N. Djokovic – J. Tsonga Head to Head Game Statistics |publisher=Tennis.wettpoint.com |access-date=19 January 2019}}{{cite web |url=http://noticiasdeltenis.wordpress.com/2012/10/07/evolution-of-djokovic-vs-tsonga-rivalry |title=Evolution of Djokovic vs Tsonga rivalry |publisher=Noticiasdeltenis.wordpress.com |date=7 October 2012 |access-date=27 January 2013}} Their first meeting was in the final of the [[2008 Australian Open]] which Djokovic won in four sets to win his first Grand Slam singles title.{{cite web |author=Nic MacBean |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2008-01-27/battling-djokovic-outlasts-tsonga/1024970 |title=Battling Djokovic outlasts Tsonga |date=27 January 2008 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |access-date=27 January 2013}} Their next meeting at a Grand Slam event was also at the [[2010 Australian Open|Australian Open]] in the 2010 quarterfinals. This time Tsonga prevailed, winning in five sets after Djokovic fell ill during the match.{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2010-01-28/ill-djokovic-hands-tsonga-victory/311598 |title=Ill Djokovic hands Tsonga victory |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=28 January 2010 |access-date=27 January 2013}} It would be another year-and-a-half until they met again, this time in the semi-finals at [[2011 Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon]] in 2011. It was their first meeting on grass, and Djokovic prevailed in four sets to advance to his first Wimbledon final.{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-07-02/nadal-djokovic-to-face-off-in-final/2779978 |title=Nadal, Djokovic to face off in final |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=2 July 2011 |access-date=27 January 2013}} In the process, Djokovic ended the seven-and-a-half-year reign of Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal at the top of the rankings. At the [[2012 French Open]], Djokovic and Tsonga met again in the quarterfinals, with Djokovic prevailing in five sets after more than four hours of play.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/tennis/frenchopen/9312603/French-Open-2012-Novak-Djokovic-reaches-semi-finals-with-thrilling-victory-over-Jo-Wilfried-Tsonga.html the first (of three) round robin matches.{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-11-06/djokovic-beats-tsonga-in-london/4355220?section=sport |title=Djokovic downs Tsonga at Tour Finals |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=6 November 2012 |access-date=27 January 2013}} It was Djokovic's fifth win over Tsonga in 2012. Their final Grand Slam tournament meeting was in the second round of the [[2019 Australian Open]],{{cite news |title=Australian Open 2019: Novak Djokovic beats Jo-Wilfried Tsonga to reach third round |publisher=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/46907455 |access-date=19 January 2019}} which Djokovic won in straight sets. ==Legacy== Some observers, tennis players and coaches describe
